sub_topic: Prove that the power set of a set is always larger than the set itself.
message_1: What is the power set of the set {1, 2, 3}? Show that the power set has more elements than the set itself.
message_2:
The power set of a set is the set of all possible subsets, including the empty set and the set itself. The power set of the set {1, 2, 3} is:

P({1, 2, 3}) = { {}, {1}, {2}, {3}, {1, 2}, {1, 3}, {2, 3}, {1, 2, 3} }

There are 8 elements in the power set P({1, 2, 3}).

The original set {1, 2, 3} has 3 elements.

Since 8 > 3, the power set has more elements than the original set itself.
